deployment/keystone/keystone-container-p.message: This assumes memcache is colocated with the keystone service. It generally is, but could not be. This is why we usually throw something like this in puppet-tripleo to collect the actual servers.  That being said we all know python memcache doesn't play well with multiple servers when one goes down so I'm not completely sure the best approach here.

Yeah - this is just something I noticed doing a relatively straight-forward deploy following the tripleo docs.

Open to suggestions on how to handle this if folks have ideas. I figured the performance benefit of at least tying into the available memecached instance would be beneficial.
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/683010/ has already been done. we just need to expose enable_token_caching

as Alex mentions, i think we need to do this in puppet-tripleo. we already have a variable there for memcached_ips. The issue is that memcached::listen_ip defaults to the internal_api IP of the server that looks up that hiera value, so if you've deployed with roles that have keystone and memcached on separate roles, then this would actually leave keystone misconfigured.

I guess we can assume it can be enabled by default, or a add a new flag to toggle setting it.

keystone/models/token_model.py.message: Doesn't this also need the domain_id if there is one?

Yeah. Technically, I don't think we intended to leak the domain_id via the token response at all, but we accidentally did when support for domain-specific roles was added to the role object. Then, we never filtered that attribute from our token response. We just passed the object through from the role API.

Ultimately, we're making sure we don't populate domain_id in the token response period. Based on how this works, it's actually not possible to have anything *but* None as a domain_id in this case (making it less than useful, anyway).
We only hit this case if there isn't a domain ID. If that's what you're asking?
Oh, I missed that. So we don't include domain-specific roles in the token at all for trusts?

this is a total style nit, but how about:

      'A policy rule ...'

just to avoid the massive hanging indent

having scope_type can be challenging sometime. Even with default to PROJECT_ADMIN, some API might want to open up the system scope also for the case when operator want to override these rule to allow system users.

One example is from nova use case, where we kept the scope_type to ['system', 'project'] for live migration API and they are default to SYSTEM_ADMIN - https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/3a6c1cbc3a07814b3fecfdc23f28da9294779bcc/nova/policies/migrate_server.py#L35

So that operator can override the rule to allow some project users to perform live migration operation on their server.
Yeah - I'm convinced this should be handled in the rule that references these rules... (if that makes sense?)

The default should be restrictive:  an API that is SYSTEM_ADMIN should not be (default) allowed by PROJECT_ADMIN semantics.  An operator that wants to open any api to a wider audience should make that rule explicit.  So if you change migrate_server to SYSTEM_ADMIN, that should also change the scope type.
nit: wonder would it help to just put this on one line and #noqa it?

One open thing here is if these can be used as it is on project side or not. In nova, we define the common base rul and added the deprecated legacy rules common rule like admin_api which helped us to deprecate only common rules not every specific rule.

I think for nova case, policies are very large so doing it in common rules was much needed but for other services policy it will be good to do deprecation at specific rule level?

- https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/3a6c1cbc3a07814b3fecfdc23f28da9294779bcc/nova/policies/base.py#L106

This is incorrect. Today neutron accept such update and ignores the resource request. This logic was needed as min bw dataplane enforcement was implemented first. And that supported such change. So when placement enforcement was added neutron did not want to break the data plane enforcement case by rejecting such request that is hard to support for placement enforcement.

I would go for keep the behavior of other QoS types, allow the update from None to valid QoS, as when the dataplane enforcement will be ready for min pps there should be user who do not use scheduling for it.

As above do we need to keep supporting adding min_bw rule? I.e. QoS(pps) -> QoS(pps,bw) case?

old Qos                       |  new Qos                               |     action
============================================================================================================
minbw=None monpps="something" |  minbw="something" minpps="something"  |   no res.request for minbw and do for minpps if there's a change
                              |                                        |
minbw="something" minpps=None |  minbw="something" minpps="something"  |   no res.request for minpps and do for minbw if there's a change    
                              |                                        |
minbw=None minpps=None        |  minbw="something" minpps="something"  |   no res.request for minpps and for minbw
@Lajos: do you mean no resource request at all, or selectively keeping pps resource request in the port but not adding bw resource request after the Qos policy update?
hm, checking the code and chatting: the resource request is filled every time even if we change from None to "something" the QoS for the port
yes but withou resource request to avoid rescheduling
No resource request at all, nor for min bw nor for min pps, and that way we will have the same behaviour.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/cert_alarm/u.message: The reason we need to use signature instead of certtype is because we could have multiple ssl_ca certs installed. (So if we support multiple certs for other types, we would have to use signature for that types of certs as well). I would think eventually using signature is better than certtype. For now I think it's ok (because the API returns certtypes now).

Correct. A 'certtype' in case of ssl_ca would just return a 'ssl_ca' and we wouldnt be able to differentiate. Hence the use of 'signature' key for ssl_ca cert types. The rest of this feature has been designed with using that unique certname across the service.
I think this is fine although a KeyError here will raise an exception, breaking the loop, so if there was a valid value later in the cert_list, we wont return it.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/conductor/ma.message: Based on the comment, since requests will timeout after 5 seconds, should we make this longer so that we see the exception from the setup calls. Basically differentiate between the cluster being down and just this specific call taking too long? So something >5s?

If it is not possible to do the setup calls, it won't be able to call the method to enable msgr2. See https://opendev.org/starlingx/utilities/src/branch/master/ceph/python-cephclient/python-cephclient/cephclient/client.py#L188 from lines 189 - 194. _get_password and _get_service_url are called previous to actually doing the post call in https://opendev.org/starlingx/utilities/src/branch/master/ceph/python-cephclient/python-cephclient/cephclient/client.py#L215

So it will be possible to differentiate the errors looking at log messages.

What could happen is the messages from enable_msgr2 be the same as those from doing the setup calls. In that case it would only be possible to differentiate the calls by looking at the time the messages are appearing in logs.

I think increasing this from 5s to 10s is good enough, another approach would be to time how long the operation took and log it, but I think it is not needed.
I think this is fine, although I think the LOG.info on the next line is not always going to be correct, if it does timeout.

I'm not too familiar with this but I thought we have existing key manager code, like in nova/keymgr/conf_key_mgr.py. I wondered if using castellan [1] would be a good idea but I see that the content in ^ is derived from castellan.key_manager. I'm asking about this because when I first read it I thought it meant something new would be implemented into the base class. 

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/castellan/latest/user/index.html

Apologies for the confusion, the generic code in the base imagebackend class I'm alluding to here is wrapper code that will generate, store and later fetch secrets using the APIs provided by Castellan.

ConfKeyManager is just our in-tree configuration based Castellan key manager that's used for testing when we don't have Barbican in the env. 

Looking through the codebase again this should likely live in nova.crypto with the vTPM stuff that's caching an instance of the key manager already for us. TBH some of my encrypted volume code that predates this could also move there.
Probably a dumb question but this intentionally does not say like "V1" in it, does that mean the same trait could be used for a theoretical v2 and it just means LUKS in general?

I think I've gone back and fourth on this a few times but yeah initially this would default to v1 and if v2 support was ever introduced we could add version specific traits. The actual format used by the disks is stored elsewhere so this is just used for scheduling and compatibility checks etc.

So with this new encryption support, deployers won't have to configure anything in their nova.confs? (I was a tad confused about the wording "this current implementation" on L24. I thought it was saying this new way would require that but after re-reading it sounds like that's the old way).
Yeah the old way was config driven, this new implementation isn't. I'll make that clear on L24.

heat/engine/stack.py.message:
I'm not entirely convinced by this. updated_at is controlled by the code but created_at is just the time the row was inserted in the database, so it's essentially meaningless for ordering. I'd be tempted to just use `datetime.datetime.utcfromtimestamp(0)`.

If it's possible it would be interesting to see a dump of the DB resources to figure out exactly what the state we're working with here is, since clearly I failed to anticipate this case.

I am unfamiliar with heat's code, and just guessed from context that the sorting should select the newest resource when multiple resources have the same score.

The bug occurs when there are multiple failed and replaced resources, and at least one of them has been replaced without getting updated, but its `current_template_id` is not `self.t.id` nor `prev_raw_template_id`.

When using `datetime.datetime.utcfromtimestamp(0)`, those never-updated resources would be ignored in favor of older, updated resources, which doesn't seem right to me, but I can't estimate if there even is a case where it would matter.

script to reproduce the bug:
https://paste.opendev.org/show/810362/

selective database dump of the `test-quota` stack created by the script:
https://paste.opendev.org/show/810363/

The goal of this code is to be able to roll back to an existing, previously-replaced resource without having to replace it again if that's possible.

It looks like the problem is there a resource in UPDATE_FAILED and one in CREATE_FAILED which both have replacements, so they both get score -31. Since they have the same score the timestamps are compared, and these differ in type (since the UPDATE_FAILED once has an update timestamp) and thus the comparison fails.

No resource that's in a FAILED status can be reused, so I don't think ordering matters at all. There's actually no timestamp in this DB table that has the semantics we want here, but I guess if you ignore races then created_at is most likely to give the right answer in some other unforeseen scenario so it's probably as good as anything.

Thanks for the extra detail, that was helpful.

Thanks for the discussion, and explanation

We do not add deliverables to a release after MembershipFreeze (milestone-2)... and even less after the release is out! Historical consistency in what makes "the OpenStack release" is important, especially for downstream stakeholders.

The right course of action here is to push the tag manually, outside of the openstack/releases machinery. That way it will not document tap-as-a-service as part of the "Xena release" even if it has a stable/xena branch. This is how it was released in pre-xena times. We'll use openstack/releases for Yoga onward.

Can we schedule a chat to better discuss requirements for this change? It could be there are better ways to archive your goals with tobiko infrared plugin.

At the end its ansible roles should ve accessible to other infrared plugins after the first time tobiko infrared command has been executed the first time.

The tobiko-run role should be your entry point to run test cases. Therefore tu run your test cases during update you could even do it from inside your own playbook or infrared plugin.

But probably before running update or upgrade stage you could want to create tobiko workloads to be later consumed from tobiko test cases during update.

What do you think?

Tobiko was not initially intended for testing control plane, but there is possibility to do it with it. Most of tobiko test cases are using control plana anyway to gather informations to perform data plane verification. I think if you want to get the best from tobiko is anyway pre allocating resources before upgrade starts and then allow tobiko to use such existing resources to quickly check APIs work against such resources. Therefore you workflow would be:

- 1st tobiko stage (also creates resources)
- upgrade stage(s)
  - ...
  - update prepare
  - verify tobiko resources and openstack APIs
  - controller update
  - verify tobiko resources and openstack APIs
  - compute update
  - verify tobiko resources and openstack APIs
  - coverage
  - verify tobiko resources and openstack APIs
  ...
- 2nd tobiko stage (only test resources and APIs

Please note tobiko test cases could be run as ansible roles from inside of another infrared plugin after tobiko plugin was previously run once.

The repeated tobiko step run during the upgrade could do the same as the 2nd tobiko stage we already created for testing after upgrades. The only difference between all these repeated steps should be the target report files, so that we can understand when things where going wrong during upgrade.

Please note this should be pretty simple to implement without any change to tobiko and we could use saved time to improve tobiko test cases for the missing APIs tests you consider we should add to tobiko (or to make a good selection of desired test cases for your job).

Cheers
Federico

Sorry I missed our face to face past week. I am going to reschedule it.

Cheers.
Federico

> Can we schedule a chat to better discuss requirements for this change? It could > be there are better ways to archive your goals with tobiko infrared plugin.

Definitively.

The test usage for now is not on having some workload that stay up during update, but on testing that the control plane is still working *during* the update process. To this end running some neutron and nova tests is perfectly fine.

You can see the "driver" for tobiko in there https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-upgrade/+/817764/3/templates/tu-tobiko.sh

Then it's run at several time during the update:
 - after update prepare;
 - after controller update;
 - after compute update ...
 - after converge

(can be seen there https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-upgrade/+/817764/3/tasks/update/main.yml)

git_review/cmd.py.message: Oh, good point about the rsplit(), so it's effectively the same as if you'd done split()[-1]. I suppose the odds another word will be added to the end of the string are considerably less.

While this is a good start at failing forward in case the version string changes in the future, it's still a bit fragile. Consider that a word could be added to the beginning of the string, causing the int recasting below to raise ValueError (e.g. "The git version is 3.45.6").

We do an rsplit so it should really only be a problem if the version string isn't the end of the line. However, this code does try to fallback to using --rebase-merges if it cannot find the version. We can update this to also catch the cast errors should they happen and just continue on.

For my current git checkout it get

 $ ~/programs/git/git version
 git version 2.34.0.1.g01cc505b7f.dirty

the git tag here breaking the int casting.  It's unfortunately not PEP440 compliant, so the parsing utils don't help.  But it looks pretty strictly semver, so I think a better idea is to do 
 
 # custom builds may look like "2.34.0.1.g01cc505b7f.dirty", only consider first 3
 tuple(map(int, v.split('.')[0:3]))

I'd also suggest raising an error that we can't determine the version, because that's going to be less confusing than using wrong flags.

Printing a warning is probably in order, but if we cease to be able to guess the git version because of a future change in the layout of the version string then we can fairly safely assume it's newer than whatever old problem behavior we're switching on. On the other hand if the program just refuses to work in that situation, then we're not being especially forward-compatible and users will have to wait for a new version of git-review before they can use it with their shiny new git.

fair point, failing probably isn't helpful.  i still think that for wide compatibility just taking the first 3 elements is best, although i also agree i tested a few systems that i thought might add things (gentoo and a homebrew installation via mac) and both didn't.

cinder/tests/unit/volume/drivers/netapp/.message: It looks like this is where you are creating a "test lun," which you then clone at L853.

Maybe I'm missing something due to not being familiar with the netapp test code, but I need help understanding how this unit test verifies the patch fixes the bug.

This is the function you're trying to test, but it's not clear to me how/where you are validating the change. I expected to see something that verified the "zapi_args" passed to the subsequent call to create_node_with_children() (the call made by clone_lun) would *NOT* include the 'space-reserve' arg when is_sub_clone is false.

In fact, the validation is done by the `clone_create` variable. This variable is built with the expected XML. In case the block_count is 0 (no block count), in the L837, the XML contains the `space-reserve`. Otherwise, the block_count is passed down and the expected XML `clone_create` does not contain the `space-reserve`.

Finally, we call the function `clone_lun`, passing the block_count (0 or 1). Then, check that the `invoke_successfully` was called with a XML matching the expected one (`clone_create`). 

Although the names and order are a bit confusing, the test is validating that the built XML has the expected values with space-reserve and block_count (the bug fix here).

OK, now I understand. The clone_create variable represents the expected results, and you verify this is what's generated by the clone_lun() function (the one you're testing) by seeing if it generates that same XML that ultimately gets passed into invoke_successfully().

I agree that a comment and renaming the clone_create variable would help the reader, but otherwise the code looks good.
I agree that it would be good to rename the variable and add some comment to help the reader. I'll update the code. Thanks Alan and Felipe.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Just a small note on libvirt's destroy() behavior, it doesn't quite pull the plug right away:

When you destroy(), first libvirt sends a SIGTERM to the guest, and waits for 10 seconds to allow it (i.e. the QEMU process) to gracefully clean up the resources.  If the guest still "refuses to die", _then_ libvirt sends the more lethal SIGKILL, and waits for 30 seconds (it used to be 5 seconds) for it to take effect.  Once SIGKILL takes effect, that's the point of no return, "sorry, I've pulled the plug."
Good points - so what does qemu do when it receives the TERM, and then the KILL? Does it attempt to ACPI shutdown the guest? Also, if this is what destroy() does, what's the point of poweroff()?

we likely called poweroff to allow a longer timeout then the 5 seconds that destroy used to do

if a process gets sig kill while its processign sig term typically the kill interupts the graceful shutdown and it gets killed forcefully. so it would be like doing a real shutdown and the power going out mid way through

This is a behavioural change for operators. Previously, we were litterally destroying the instance without waiting while now we propose to wait until the guest gracefully shuts down.

There could be some impacts we could be missing. At least a blueprint and here a relnote are important for telling about this change.

i think we might want to just replace this with 

self._power_off_instance instead.

No, I think it makes sense to keep them separate. The methods are named badly, but they do different things.

When you don't care about the guest OS and want to save time, you _shutdown_instance() to just get rid of it.

When you have to care about the guest, you _power_off_instance() gracefully first.

In *libvirt*, driver.power_off() happens to call driver.destory() eventually, so _power_off_instance() will also destroy it from the hypervisor, but we cannot make that assumption for all drivers. We need the two separate methods in the compute manager.
instead of doing this here which likely will work fine i would suggest we move it to inside _shutdown_instance

I'm not convinced, because wasting time waiting for the guest to power off gracefully when we don't care isn't an improvement. As I said in my comment above, I think these should remain separate calls.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Rebased on top of https://review.opendev.org/c/x/tobiko/+/816505 to make sure it works.

I think it would be far simpler to use conditional resource creation feature from heat templates. What you should do is defining a boolean in stack class that says if has_healthmonitor. This should be false for OVN provider, True for Amphora provider.
Then this should be passed as a boolean to the template and the value of the parameter should be used to create a condition. For example look at the nova serve template how to do it: https://opendev.org/x/tobiko/src/branch/master/tobiko/openstack/stacks/nova/server.yaml#L89-L98

Finally you can use the condition field to make healthmonitor resource creation conditional and its its related output value.

tobiko/openstack/octavia/_validators.py.message: I would remane this as last_content

I think members_count is the the factor you should look it. Pool_id is only a way to have the member_count:

   if lf_algorithm == 'ROUND_ROBIN' and member_count > 1:
In some cases (like test_traffic) I do not pass the member_count parameter, so I use the pool_id in order to get it.

I would raise a special error here:

  if content == last_content:
      raise RoundRobinError(...)
  
so you can capture this error type later instead
I agree, I will raise this error instead, thanks.

We should better look at below condition:
  members_count > 1

The fact pool_id is given is just a way to set members_count variable that it is the fact that counts here for the algorithm verification perspective.

  if last_content is not None:
    if member_count == 1 and last_content != content:
      raise octavia.RoundRobinException(
        'Request not forwarded to the same host:\n'
        f'  members_count: {members_count}\n'
        f'  expected: {last_content}\n',
        f'  actual: {content}\n')
      elif member_count != 1 and last_content == content:
        raise octavia.RoundRobinException(
          'Request forwarded twice to the same host:\n'
          f'  members_count: {members_count}\n'
          f'  expected: {last_content}\n',
          f'  actual: {content}\n')

The first condition (if member_count == 1 and last_content != content) can never happen.

In case there is only one member, it will get the traffic. The traffic cannot reach any other member or endpoint.

The next traffic that will reach the (single) member will have the same output, so an exception won't be raised.

The second condition seems to be something we agree on. Thanks.

I think it'd be better to do something like....

    - name: Set IP options
      set_fact:
        _sed_opts: "{{ (':' in controller) | ternary('s/.*dev \\(.*\\) table.*/\\1/', 's/.*dev \\(.*\\) src.*/\\1/') }}"
        _ping_cmd: "{{ (':' in controller) | ternary('ping6', 'ping') }}"
    - name: Lookup interface information
      register: _nic_mtu
      shell: |
        INT=$(ip ro get {{ controller }} | head -1 | sed '{{ _sed_opts }}')
        MTU=$(cat /sys/class/net/${INT}/mtu 2>/dev/null || echo "0")
        echo "$INT $MTU"
    - name: Set interface vars
      set_fact:
        _nic: "{{ _nic_mtu.get('stdout', '').split(' ')[0] | default('lo') }}"
        _mtu: "{{ _nic_mtu.get('stdout', '').split(' ')[1] | default(0) | int - 28 }}"
    - name: Network availability validation block
      block:
      - name: Check IP responsiveness
        command: "{{ _ping_cmd }} -w 10 -c 1 {{ controller }}"
        retries: 10
        delay: 60
        changed_when: false

      - name: Validate packet with {{ _mtu }} MTU size can reach controller from {{ _nic }}
        command: "{{ _ping_cmd }} -w 10 -s {{ _mtu }} -c 1 {{ controller }}"
        retries: 10
        delay: 60
        changed_when: false
        when: _mtu | int > 0
      when: _nic != 'lo'

Some minor corrections and inline question.

This is not the right approach.  The "official" data for kubeadm is stored in the kubeadm-config configmap in the kube-system namespace, and when we upgrade kubernetes the kube-apiserver manifest will be re-written based on the contents of that configmap.  I have confirmed that editing the configmap to add the feature gate is enough to cause the change to take effect on the next kubernetes upgrade.  I think this is the proper approach for the kube-apiserver feature gate change.

The kubelet-config-1.xx configmap gets created (by kubeadm, I'm pretty sure) for each version of kubernetes that we run.  So after upgrading we'll have configmaps for 1.18, 1.19, 1.20, and 1.21.  I haven't yet figured out exactly when these get created or whether we can edit them before  /var/lib/kubelet/config.yaml gets written.  But we'd want to ensure that /var/lib/kubelet/config.yaml is modified specifically for k8s 1.21 so it's not sufficient to change it at the time of the platform upgrade.

When running the "kubeadm upgrade apply" command, it's possible to use the '--config' option to specify a yaml file with additional configuration options.

By passing in a yaml file that looks like this:

---
kind: KubeletConfiguration
apiVersion: kubelet.config.k8s.io/v1beta1
cgroupDriver: cgroupfs

It's possible to tell kubeadm to modify the kubelet configuration to use the cgroupfs cgroup driver.

controllerconfig/controllerconfig/upgrad.message: reword to something like, 'explicitly configure this option in'

Can see the Zuul bash lint reason for this.
You can manually run bashate lint on the file, or wait for subsqent zuul job.
There is also manual way to run tox if you like, there is a bit of setup process for that.

I think bash convention these days is:
Change most variables to look like this to prevent interpolation issues:
${current_kube_version}

And further put in quotes on the RHS, e.g., "${current_kube_version}", if you interpret the lint message message recommendation. ;-)

you are right, should really quote LHS and RHS to be consistent.

I think rationale for quoting variables is to prevent the test from breaking with syntax error in the case the variable is empty, eg, [ -eq 1 ] has no LHS in the condition.

The bash [[ builtin has less quirks, and bash gives some grace with various comparisons without complaining.

The ${variable} is for variable expansion and dereferencing array elements, eg, ${array[0]} .

The difference between "$varbar" and "${var}bar", the second will expand $var and append bar, the first will expand ${varbar}.
Wouldn't you need quotes on both LHS and RHS, not just the RHS?

Unless this script is only called when version is 1.20, this exit will cause upgrade failure if this script is called for non 1.20 versions. Since we have tested these parameters work when configuring back to 1.18, 1.19, 1.20, and 1.21, I think it would be simpler to not do the kubernetes version check at all, just always make those inline sed changes. It won't hurt.

If you want to abort script with success, you would need to exit 0. If you did that though, would be more obvious to caller to handle a return code from the function so it is obvious where it aborts.

As discussed I think we probably want to create this user in the container, but this is a good start to determine what else we need to do

if the backedn declares itself as plug-time-unreliable we should wait for events at plug time but not

as noted in the top level comment we could also wait for the unplug event.
we normally dont  do that but it would get rid fo the unexpect vif unplugged event warning.

Nova never waits for the unplug event. Technically we can wait for it during hard_reboot. However then we need two separate workaround config flags as networking-odl only sends plug events but not unplug events during unplug/plug. See the limitation here [1]. 

Also I think waiting for the plug is enough if we can assume that the networking backend does not have a race between unplug and plug. (and I do assume that :D)

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/networking-odl/src/branch/master/networking_odl/ml2/port_status_update.py#L89-L90

David,

The symlink is only necessary in development mode (through a pip installation of validations-libs). 
Pip will always install stuffs in /usr/local/ if you install vlibs with sudo (not recommended btw, I will address a comment in your patch about the vagrantfile asap ;) or in $VIRTUALENV_DIR/share/ if you use a non-root user.

/usr/share/ansible/validation-playbooks/ is the default place in validations_libs/constants.py [1] and this is the place where the VF is supposed to find out the validations playbooks served by our official rpms.

Then what we display in this log.debug message is what we pass by default through the validations_libs/cli/run.py ([2] & [3]) which calls the validations_libs.validation_actions.run_validations(..)[4] 
That's why we always display the same absolute path whatever the validations type, official or community one.

Hope it clears the confusion 🙏

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/validations-libs/src/branch/master/validations_libs/constants.py#L27-L31
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/validations-libs/src/branch/master/validations_libs/cli/run.py#L49-L52
[3] https://opendev.org/openstack/validations-libs/src/branch/master/validations_libs/cli/run.py#L211
[4] https://opendev.org/openstack/validations-libs/src/branch/master/validations_libs/validation_actions.py#L422

Is this true universally?  On the Ubuntu Vagrant for example it's a different path and we need a symlink to fix it.

Should we address that or keep with the symlink hack?

[sysadmin@controller-0 ~(keystone_admin)]$ system service-parameter-apply platform

information

It seems like this could yield duplicate build. Here is a scenario:

- fetch page 0 returns build [0..10]
- new build gets reported, the database now has [-5..]
- fetch page 1 returns build [5..15]

Thus we need to keep track of yielded build uuids to ensure we don't yield a build more than one time.
Actually, I don't think that is correct, I though the builds result would be ordered by end_time, but it is not the case and more recent build can be found after an old one.
Not sure when is this `--job-name` argument supposed to be used. Shouldn't we process all the builds?
Perhaps the most recent processed build could be discovered from the logstash url?
Ditto, when is the `--ignore-checkpoint` argument supposed to be used?
why is this writing multiple line in the checkpoint file?

so if multiple jobs provided, only one file contains all the checkpoint uuids. For example:
    logscraper --job-name test --job-name test2 --checkpoint-file /tmp/checkpoint --zuul-api-url http://localhost/api/tenant/mytenant

will create a file: /tmp/checkpoint-mytenant:
    test <some uuid>
    test2 <some other uuid>

instead of

    /tmp/checkpoint-mytenant-test
    /tmp/checkpoint-mytenant-test2

and each of that file will only store uuid. I think it can be more logical to understand and track, but probably it can be less efficient.

I wonder if it is worth adding such complexity just to avoid using multiple files. At that point, we might want to use a better storage like sqlite.

But as suggested previously, perhaps we don't even need to store anything locally, and we could simply query logstash to check what was the last indexed build?
Why not keeping the generator to scan the pages (in case there are more than 100 builds to process)?

Perhaps both case could be identical, e.g.:

  pool = multiprocessing.Pool(int(args.workers) if args.workers else 1)
  try:
    pool.map(run_build, builds)
  finally:
    config.save(builds[0]['uuid'], job_name)

So that we always record the most recent build processed.

nit: such `with` context are usually not meant to be nested using the same object, It seems like this should be:

  checkpoint_text = open(checkpoint_file).readlines()
  with open(checkpoint_file, 'w') as f_out:
    ...
